skill.name: literature-review
skill.description: Conduct comprehensive, systematic literature reviews using multiple academic databases (PubMed, arXiv, bioRxiv, Semantic Scholar, etc.). This skill should be used when conducting systematic literature reviews, meta-analyses, research synthesis, or comprehensive literature searches across biomedical, scientific, and technical domains. Creates professionally formatted markdown documents and PDFs with verified citations in multiple citation styles (APA, Nature, Vancouver, etc.).

security_audit.summary: The literature-review skill is a legitimate academic research tool. Static analysis flagged many external_command patterns, but these are documentation examples showing shell commands for legitimate tools (pandoc, gget). The network requests are to standard academic APIs (CrossRef, DOI resolution) and database services. No malicious intent detected.

content.value_statement: Stop manually searching databases and formatting citations. This skill automates systematic literature reviews by searching multiple academic databases, verifying citations, and generating professional PDFs with proper academic formatting.
actual_capabilities: Search multiple academic databases (PubMed, arXiv, bioRxiv, Semantic Scholar)
Verify DOIs and generate properly formatted citations
Create professional PDFs with academic formatting
Generate PRISMA flow diagrams for systematic reviews
Format citations in APA, Nature, Vancouver, Chicago, IEEE styles
limitations: Requires external tools (pandoc, LaTeX) for PDF generation
Network access needed for database searches and citation verification
Manual screening of abstracts and full texts still required
Citation counts may not be available for all papers

use_cases.title: Thesis literature review chapters
use_cases.description: Conduct comprehensive literature searches for dissertation background sections with verified citations and professional formatting.

use_cases.title: Systematic review publications
use_cases.description: Perform systematic reviews following PRISMA guidelines with multi-database searches and quality assessment.

use_cases.title: Evidence-based medicine reviews
use_cases.description: Synthesize clinical evidence from PubMed and other medical databases for treatment decisions.

prompt_templates.title: Basic literature search
prompt_templates.scenario: Find recent papers on a topic
prompt_templates.prompt: Search PubMed and bioRxiv for recent papers (2020-2024) about CRISPR gene therapy for sickle cell disease. Focus on clinical trials and review articles.

prompt_templates.title: Systematic review
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a systematic review on the efficacy of mRNA vaccines for cancer immunotherapy. Search PubMed, bioRxiv, and arXiv. Include only peer-reviewed articles and preprints from 2018-2024.

prompt_templates.title: Citation verification
prompt_templates.prompt: Verify all DOIs and format citations in my literature review document using APA style. Generate a verification report showing any failed citations.

prompt_templates.title: Generate PDF
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert my literature review markdown to a PDF with Nature citation style, table of contents, and section numbering. Check that all dependencies are installed first.

output_examples.input: Search PubMed for CRISPR sickle cell studies from 2020-2024
output: Top result: 'CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing for sickle cell disease: a phase I/II clinical trial' (2023) - 156 citations
Use --deduplicate flag to remove duplicates when combining with other databases

best_practices: Always verify citations with verify_citations.py before finalizing your review
Search at least 3 different databases to ensure comprehensive coverage
Include visual elements like PRISMA flow diagrams using the scientific-schematics skill
anti_patterns: Don't rely on a single database - this leads to incomplete literature coverage
Avoid study-by-study summaries - organize thematically instead
Never skip citation verification - unverified citations damage credibility

faq.question: Which databases should I search?
faq.answer: For biomedical topics: PubMed, bioRxiv, and Semantic Scholar. For physics/CS: arXiv, Semantic Scholar, Google Scholar. Always use at least 3 databases.

faq.question: How do I handle duplicate papers across databases?
faq.answer: Use the --deduplicate flag in search_databases.py. It removes duplicates by DOI first, then by title matching.

faq.question: What citation styles are supported?
faq.answer: APA, Nature, Vancouver, Chicago, and IEEE. Use --citation-style flag when generating PDFs.

faq.question: Do I need to install anything?
faq.answer: For PDF generation, install pandoc and LaTeX. For searches, no installation needed - uses web APIs.

faq.question: How does citation verification work?
faq.answer: The script extracts DOIs, checks they resolve correctly, retrieves metadata from CrossRef, and formats citations properly.

faq.question: Can I include preprints?
faq.answer: Yes, bioRxiv and arXiv are supported. Always note that preprints are not peer-reviewed and verify findings carefully.
